trans-unit.source: Create a VNet-to-VNet connection using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create a VNet-to-VNet connection using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This article walks you through connecting virtual networks together by using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell
trans-unit.target: This article walks you through connecting virtual networks together by using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Connecting a virtual network to another virtual network (VNet-to-VNet) is very similar to connecting a VNet to an on-premises site location.
trans-unit.target: Connecting a virtual network to another virtual network (VNet-to-VNet) is very similar to connecting a VNet to an on-premises site location.

trans-unit.source: Both connectivity types use a VPN gateway to provide a secure tunnel using IPsec/IKE.
trans-unit.target: Both connectivity types use a VPN gateway to provide a secure tunnel using IPsec/IKE.

trans-unit.source: The VNets you connect can be in different regions.
trans-unit.target: The VNets you connect can be in different regions.

trans-unit.source: You can even combine VNet-to-VNet communication with multi-site configurations.
trans-unit.target: You can even combine VNet-to-VNet communication with multi-site configurations.

trans-unit.source: This lets you establish network topologies that combine cross-premises connectivity with inter-virtual network connectivity, as shown in the diagram below.
trans-unit.target: This lets you establish network topologies that combine cross-premises connectivity with inter-virtual network connectivity, as shown in the diagram below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet to VNet Connectivity Diagram</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet to VNet Connectivity Diagram</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Azure currently has two deployment modes: the classic deployment mode, and the Azure Resource Manager deployment mode.
trans-unit.target: Azure currently has two deployment modes: the classic deployment mode, and the Azure Resource Manager deployment mode.

trans-unit.source: The configuration cmdlets and steps differ between deployment modes.
trans-unit.target: The configuration cmdlets and steps differ between deployment modes.

trans-unit.source: This topic will walk you through connecting virtual networks that are created using the Azure Resource Manager mode.
trans-unit.target: This topic will walk you through connecting virtual networks that are created using the Azure Resource Manager mode.

trans-unit.source: If you want to create a VNet-to-VNet connection using the classic deployment mode, see <link><linkText>Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection using the Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to create a VNet-to-VNet connection using the classic deployment mode, see <link><linkText>Configure a VNet-to-VNet connection using the Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to connect a virtual network that was created in the classic mode to a virtual network created in Azure Resource Manager, see <link><linkText>Connecting classic VNets to new VNets</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to connect a virtual network that was created in the classic mode to a virtual network created in Azure Resource Manager, see <link><linkText>Connecting classic VNets to new VNets</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Why connect virtual networks?
trans-unit.target: Why connect virtual networks?

trans-unit.source: You may want to connect virtual networks for the following reasons:
trans-unit.target: You may want to connect virtual networks for the following reasons:

trans-unit.source: Cross region geo-redundancy and geo-presence
trans-unit.target: Cross region geo-redundancy and geo-presence

trans-unit.source: You can set up your own geo-replication or synchronization with secure connectivity without going over internet-facing endpoints.
trans-unit.target: You can set up your own geo-replication or synchronization with secure connectivity without going over internet-facing endpoints.

trans-unit.source: With Azure Load Balancer and Microsoft or third-party clustering technology, you can setup highly available workload with geo-redundancy across multiple Azure regions.
trans-unit.target: With Azure Load Balancer and Microsoft or third-party clustering technology, you can setup highly available workload with geo-redundancy across multiple Azure regions.

trans-unit.source: One important example is to setup SQL Always On with Availability Groups spreading across multiple Azure regions.
trans-unit.target: One important example is to setup SQL Always On with Availability Groups spreading across multiple Azure regions.

trans-unit.source: Regional multi-tier applications with strong isolation boundary
trans-unit.target: Regional multi-tier applications with strong isolation boundary

trans-unit.source: Within the same region, you can setup multi-tier applications with multiple virtual networks connected together with strong isolation and secure inter-tier communication.
trans-unit.target: Within the same region, you can setup multi-tier applications with multiple virtual networks connected together with strong isolation and secure inter-tier communication.

trans-unit.source: Items to note
trans-unit.target: Items to note

trans-unit.source: This article will walk you through connecting two virtual networks, VNet1 and VNet2.
trans-unit.target: This article will walk you through connecting two virtual networks, VNet1 and VNet2.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need to be comfortable with networking in order to substitute the IP address ranges that are compatible with your network design requirements.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need to be comfortable with networking in order to substitute the IP address ranges that are compatible with your network design requirements.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connecting VNet to VNet</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connecting VNet to VNet</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The virtual networks can be in the same or different Azure regions (locations).
trans-unit.target: The virtual networks can be in the same or different Azure regions (locations).

trans-unit.source: A cloud service or a load balancing endpoint CANNOT span across virtual networks, even if they are connected together.
trans-unit.target: A cloud service or a load balancing endpoint CANNOT span across virtual networks, even if they are connected together.

trans-unit.source: Connecting multiple Azure virtual networks together doesn't require any on-premises VPN gateways, unless cross-premises connectivity is required.
trans-unit.target: Connecting multiple Azure virtual networks together doesn't require any on-premises VPN gateways, unless cross-premises connectivity is required.

trans-unit.source: VNet-to-VNet supports connecting virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: VNet-to-VNet supports connecting virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: It does not support connecting virtual machines or cloud services NOT in a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: It does not support connecting virtual machines or cloud services NOT in a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: VNet-to-VNet requires Azure VPN gateways with RouteBased (previously called Dynamic) VPN types.
trans-unit.target: VNet-to-VNet requires Azure VPN gateways with RouteBased (previously called Dynamic) VPN types.

trans-unit.source: Virtual network connectivity can be used simultaneously with multi-site VPNs, with a maximum of 10 VPN tunnels for a virtual network VPN gateway connecting to ether other virtual networks or on-premises sites.
trans-unit.target: Virtual network connectivity can be used simultaneously with multi-site VPNs, with a maximum of 10 VPN tunnels for a virtual network VPN gateway connecting to ether other virtual networks or on-premises sites.

trans-unit.source: The address spaces of the virtual networks and on-premises local network sites must not overlap.
trans-unit.target: The address spaces of the virtual networks and on-premises local network sites must not overlap.

trans-unit.source: Overlapping address spaces will cause the creation of virtual networks to fail.
trans-unit.target: Overlapping address spaces will cause the creation of virtual networks to fail.

trans-unit.source: Redundant tunnels between a pair of virtual networks are not supported.
trans-unit.target: Redundant tunnels between a pair of virtual networks are not supported.

trans-unit.source: All VPN tunnels of the virtual network share the available bandwidth on the Azure VPN gateway and the same VPN gateway uptime SLA in Azure.
trans-unit.target: All VPN tunnels of the virtual network share the available bandwidth on the Azure VPN gateway and the same VPN gateway uptime SLA in Azure.

trans-unit.source: VNet-to-VNet traffic travels across the Azure backbone.
trans-unit.target: VNet-to-VNet traffic travels across the Azure backbone.

trans-unit.source: Before beginning
trans-unit.target: Before beginning

trans-unit.source: Before you begin, verify that you have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin, verify that you have the following:

trans-unit.source: The latest version of Azure PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: The latest version of Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the <link><linkText>Download page</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the <link><linkText>Download page</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can activate your <link><linkText>MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or sign up for a <link><linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can activate your <link><linkText>MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or sign up for a <link><linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you already have created your virtual networks, see <link><linkText>Connecting existing VNets</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you already have created your virtual networks, see <link><linkText>Connecting existing VNets</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple steps to creating and configuring a VNet-to-VNet connection.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple steps to creating and configuring a VNet-to-VNet connection.

trans-unit.source: Configure each section in the order listed below.
trans-unit.target: Configure each section in the order listed below.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Plan your IP address ranges</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Plan your IP address ranges</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Connect to your subscription</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Connect to your subscription</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create a virtual network</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create a virtual network</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Request a public IP address for your gateway</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Request a public IP address for your gateway</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create the gateway configuration</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create the gateway configuration</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create the gateway</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create the gateway</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Repeat to configure VNet2</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Repeat to configure VNet2</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Connect the VPN gateways</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Connect the VPN gateways</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Plan your IP address ranges
trans-unit.target: Plan your IP address ranges

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: It’s important to decide the ranges that you’ll use to configure your network configuration.
trans-unit.target: It’s important to decide the ranges that you’ll use to configure your network configuration.

trans-unit.source: From the perspective of VNet1, VNet2 is just another VPN connection that’s defined in the Azure platform.
trans-unit.target: From the perspective of VNet1, VNet2 is just another VPN connection that’s defined in the Azure platform.

trans-unit.source: And from VNet2, VNet1 is just another VPN connection.
trans-unit.target: And from VNet2, VNet1 is just another VPN connection.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind that you must make sure that none of your VNet ranges or local network ranges overlap in any way.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind that you must make sure that none of your VNet ranges or local network ranges overlap in any way.

trans-unit.source: In the steps below, we’ll create two virtual networks along with their respective gateway subnets and configurations.
trans-unit.target: In the steps below, we’ll create two virtual networks along with their respective gateway subnets and configurations.

trans-unit.source: We'll then create a VPN gateway connection between the two VNets.
trans-unit.target: We'll then create a VPN gateway connection between the two VNets.

trans-unit.source: For this exercise, use the following values for the VNets:
trans-unit.target: For this exercise, use the following values for the VNets:

trans-unit.source: Values for VNet1:
trans-unit.target: Values for VNet1:

trans-unit.source: Virtual Network Name = VNet1
trans-unit.target: Virtual Network Name = VNet1

trans-unit.source: Resource Group = testrg1
trans-unit.target: Resource Group = testrg1

trans-unit.source: Address Space = 10.1.0.0/16
trans-unit.target: Address Space = 10.1.0.0/16

trans-unit.source: Region = US West
trans-unit.target: Region = US West

trans-unit.source: GatewaySubnet = 10.1.0.0/28
trans-unit.target: GatewaySubnet = 10.1.0.0/28

trans-unit.source: Values for VNet2:
trans-unit.target: Values for VNet2:

trans-unit.source: Virtual Network Name = VNet2
trans-unit.target: Virtual Network Name = VNet2

trans-unit.source: Resource Group = testrg2
trans-unit.target: Resource Group = testrg2

trans-unit.source: Address Space = 10.2.0.0/16
trans-unit.target: Address Space = 10.2.0.0/16

trans-unit.source: Region = Japan East
trans-unit.target: Region = Japan East

trans-unit.source: GatewaySubnet = 10.2.0.0/28
trans-unit.target: GatewaySubnet = 10.2.0.0/28

trans-unit.source: Connect to your subscription
trans-unit.target: Connect to your subscription

trans-unit.source: Step 2
trans-unit.target: Step 2

trans-unit.source: Open your PowerShell console and switch to the Azure Resource Manager mode.
trans-unit.target: Open your PowerShell console and switch to the Azure Resource Manager mode.

trans-unit.source: Use the following sample to help you connect:
trans-unit.target: Use the following sample to help you connect:

trans-unit.source: Use the Select-AzureSubscription to connect to the subscription that you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Use the Select-AzureSubscription to connect to the subscription that you want to use.

trans-unit.source: Next, switch to the ARM mode.
trans-unit.target: Next, switch to the ARM mode.

trans-unit.source: This will switch the mode to allow you to use the ARM cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: This will switch the mode to allow you to use the ARM cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Create a virtual network
trans-unit.target: Create a virtual network

trans-unit.source: Step 3
trans-unit.target: Step 3

trans-unit.source: Use the sample below to create a virtual network and a gateway subnet.
trans-unit.target: Use the sample below to create a virtual network and a gateway subnet.

trans-unit.source: Substitute the values for your own.
trans-unit.target: Substitute the values for your own.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we'll create VNet1.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we'll create VNet1.

trans-unit.source: You'll repeat the steps to create VNet2 later.
trans-unit.target: You'll repeat the steps to create VNet2 later.

trans-unit.source: First, create a Resource Group.
trans-unit.target: First, create a Resource Group.

trans-unit.source: Next, create your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Next, create your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: The sample below creates a virtual network named VNet1 and two subnets, one called GatewaySubnet and the other called Subnet1.
trans-unit.target: The sample below creates a virtual network named VNet1 and two subnets, one called GatewaySubnet and the other called Subnet1.

trans-unit.source: It's important to create one subnet named specifically GatewaySubnet.
trans-unit.target: It's important to create one subnet named specifically GatewaySubnet.

trans-unit.source: If you name it something else, your connection configuration will fail.
trans-unit.target: If you name it something else, your connection configuration will fail.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, our gateway subnet is using a /28.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, our gateway subnet is using a /28.

trans-unit.source: You may choose to use a gateway subnet as small as /29.
trans-unit.target: You may choose to use a gateway subnet as small as /29.

trans-unit.source: Note that some features (such as an ExpressRoute/site-to-site coexist connection) require a larger gateway subnet of /27, so you may want to create your gateway subnet to accommodate additional features you may use in the future.
trans-unit.target: Note that some features (such as an ExpressRoute/site-to-site coexist connection) require a larger gateway subnet of /27, so you may want to create your gateway subnet to accommodate additional features you may use in the future.

trans-unit.source: Request a public IP address
trans-unit.target: Request a public IP address

trans-unit.source: Step 4
trans-unit.target: Step 4

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll request a public IP address to be allocated to the gateway you will create for your VNet.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll request a public IP address to be allocated to the gateway you will create for your VNet.

trans-unit.source: You cannot specify the IP address that you want to use; it’s dynamically allocated to your gateway.
trans-unit.target: You cannot specify the IP address that you want to use; it’s dynamically allocated to your gateway.

trans-unit.source: You'll use this IP address in the next configuration section.
trans-unit.target: You'll use this IP address in the next configuration section.

trans-unit.source: Use the sample below.
trans-unit.target: Use the sample below.

trans-unit.source: The Allocation Method for this address must be Dynamic.
trans-unit.target: The Allocation Method for this address must be Dynamic.

trans-unit.source: Create the gateway configuration
trans-unit.target: Create the gateway configuration

trans-unit.source: Step 5
trans-unit.target: Step 5

trans-unit.source: The gateway configuration defines the subnet and the public IP address to use.
trans-unit.target: The gateway configuration defines the subnet and the public IP address to use.

trans-unit.source: Use the sample below to create your gateway configuration.
trans-unit.target: Use the sample below to create your gateway configuration.

trans-unit.source: Create the gateway
trans-unit.target: Create the gateway

trans-unit.source: Step 6
trans-unit.target: Step 6

trans-unit.source: In this step, you'll create the virtual network gateway for your VNet.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you'll create the virtual network gateway for your VNet.

trans-unit.source: VNet-to-VNet configurations require a RouteBased VpnType.
trans-unit.target: VNet-to-VNet configurations require a RouteBased VpnType.

trans-unit.source: Creating a gateway can take a while, so be patient.
trans-unit.target: Creating a gateway can take a while, so be patient.

trans-unit.source: Create VNet2
trans-unit.target: Create VNet2

trans-unit.source: Step 7
trans-unit.target: Step 7

trans-unit.source: Once you've configured VNet1, repeat the previous steps to configure VNet2 along with its gateway configuration.
trans-unit.target: Once you've configured VNet1, repeat the previous steps to configure VNet2 along with its gateway configuration.

trans-unit.source: After you've completed the configuration for both of the VNets and their respective gateways, proceed to <link><linkText>Connect the gateways</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: After you've completed the configuration for both of the VNets and their respective gateways, proceed to <link><linkText>Connect the gateways</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Connect the gateways
trans-unit.target: Connect the gateways

trans-unit.source: Step 8
trans-unit.target: Step 8

trans-unit.source: In this step, you'll create the VPN gateway connections between the two virtual network gateways.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you'll create the VPN gateway connections between the two virtual network gateways.

trans-unit.source: You'll see a shared key referenced in the examples.
trans-unit.target: You'll see a shared key referenced in the examples.

trans-unit.source: You can use your own values for the shared key.
trans-unit.target: You can use your own values for the shared key.

trans-unit.source: The important thing is that the shared key must match for both configurations.
trans-unit.target: The important thing is that the shared key must match for both configurations.

trans-unit.source: When creating connections, note that they do take some time to complete.
trans-unit.target: When creating connections, note that they do take some time to complete.

trans-unit.source: For VNet1 to VNet2
trans-unit.target: For VNet1 to VNet2

trans-unit.source: For VNet2 to VNet1
trans-unit.target: For VNet2 to VNet1

trans-unit.source: After a few minutes, the connection should be established.
trans-unit.target: After a few minutes, the connection should be established.

trans-unit.source: Note that at this time, gateways and connections created with Azure Resource Manager are not visible in the Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: Note that at this time, gateways and connections created with Azure Resource Manager are not visible in the Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: Connecting existing VNets
trans-unit.target: Connecting existing VNets

trans-unit.source: If you already have created virtual networks in Azure Resource Manager mode and you want to connect them, verify the following:
trans-unit.target: If you already have created virtual networks in Azure Resource Manager mode and you want to connect them, verify the following:

trans-unit.source: You have a gateway subnet of at least /29 or larger for each VNet.
trans-unit.target: You have a gateway subnet of at least /29 or larger for each VNet.

trans-unit.source: The address ranges for your virtual networks do not overlap.
trans-unit.target: The address ranges for your virtual networks do not overlap.

trans-unit.source: If you need to add gateway subnets to your VNets, use the sample below, replacing the values with your own.
trans-unit.target: If you need to add gateway subnets to your VNets, use the sample below, replacing the values with your own.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to name the gateway subnet 'GatewaySubnet'.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to name the gateway subnet 'GatewaySubnet'.

trans-unit.source: If you name it something else, your VPN configuration will not work as expected.
trans-unit.target: If you name it something else, your VPN configuration will not work as expected.

trans-unit.source: After verifying that your gateway subnets are configured correctly, continue with <link><linkText>Request a public IP address</linkText><title></title></link> and follow the steps.
trans-unit.target: After verifying that your gateway subnets are configured correctly, continue with <link><linkText>Request a public IP address</linkText><title></title></link> and follow the steps.

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: You can add virtual machines to your virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: You can add virtual machines to your virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create a Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create a Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.
